subtitleNullable: Covid-19 related layoffs and the aftermath
descriptionNullable:
I stumbled on this dataset when searching for data for a project, and I knew I had to dig in to find what stories the data told. 

I obtained this dataset from Kaggle (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/swaptr/layoffs-2022), and it originally had 1770 rows of data. After downloading, I discovered there were many missing rows of data. I tried to compute a mode, then a mean, for the missing values, but this made the data skewed so I abandoned the idea. The data time period is 3 years – 2020- 2022 and it has 9 variables which include: company name, location, industry, number of staff laid off, percentage laid off, date of layoff, stage of funding, country, and funds raised by the company.
I ended up deleting the missing values, which left only 876 rows of data. 

Losing a job isn’t just a loss of a steady paycheck, it has far-reaching psychological implications which trigger mental health issues in individuals. Since the Covid-19 pandemic hit, a lot of companies have laid off staff, some have closed shop and many more companies will continue to lay off staff. This has made people more interested in the reasons for layoffs and their effect on the psychological, social, economic, and mental health implications. 

The purpose of this data analysis is to answer the following questions: 
o	What insights can we draw from the dataset?
o	What country has the highest number of layoffs?
o	What location?
o	Is it peculiar to an industry?
o	what top companies have the highest numbers?
o	are there certain stages in a company where the tendency to layoff staff is highest?
o	Is there a significant number of layoffs based on the date? 
o	What are the key takeaways?


I also analyzed this dataset using Tableau, please visit (https://public.tableau.com/app/profile/ema.oyeyiola/viz/Layoffs_16724822868200/Covid-19relatedLayoffsandtheaftermath) to see the visuals!
title: Exploring the Layoffs Dataset
subtitle: Covid-19 related layoffs and the aftermath
description:

I ended up deleting the missing values, which left only 876 rows of data.
